column1: Youth Advocate Programs of Pennsylvania_Intensive Outpatient Programs and Day Treatment-Youth
column10: [Follow the Next Steps to find out if this program has eligibility criteria.]
column12: Youth Advocate Programs offers an IOP program for its youth residents. IOP services are different from residential inpatient rehab programs and partial hospitalization programs in that treatment is generally part-time.  However, the intensive outpatient program is far more comprehensive than traditional outpatient programs that only consist of a few therapy sessions.  The IOP consists of numerous weekly therapy sessions at YAP's outpatient facility with experienced counselors (trained in addictions, eating disorders, etc.).Services offered:- Individual therapy- Substance abuse therapyTo make a self referral and inquire about specific services in your area please contact your local county office.
column18: This program covers residents of the following counties: Adams County, PA, Allegheny County, PA, Bedford County, PA, Berks County, PA, Bradford County, PA, Carbon County, PA, Crawford County, PA, Dauphin County, PA, Franklin County, PA, Huntingdon County, PA, Juniata County, PA, Lackawanna County, PA, Lancaster County, PA, Lebanon County, PA, Lehigh County, PA, Mercer County, PA, Mifflin County, PA, Monroe County, PA, Northampton County, PA, Philadelphia County, PA, Pike County, PA, Schuylkill County, PA, Somerset County, PA, Susquehanna County, PA, Wyoming County, PA and York County, PA.

column1: Women In Transition_Substance Abuse Intervention
column10: ['Anyone can access this program.']
column12: Substance Abuse Intervention is not a 12-step program, nor is it faith-based; however, we are respectful of each individual's spirituality. We do not require drug tests, but we do ask that you refrain from using drugs or alcohol before you come to your counseling or group sessions.Services Include:- Empowerment counseling for recoveryOur service model recognizes that change and recovery are a process and integrates the concepts of harm reduction into trauma-informed empowerment so that we can better address both relationship violence and substance abuse. Our safe and supportive services help women increase self-esteem and personal awareness about practical issues which are key to a woman's recovery. Services are free and confidential. For more information call 215-751-1111.

For those without coverage, assistance with arrangements can be made through our assessment center at 215-662-8747.

column1: The Attic Youth Center_Mental Health Counseling
column3: ['substance abuse counseling', 'counseling', 'mental health care', 'anger management', 'group therapy', 'family counseling', 'individual counseling']
column5: ['young adults', 'teens', 'immigrants', 'developmental disability', 'lgbtqia+', 'transgender or non-binary', 'individuals', 'families', 'caregivers', 'trauma survivors', 'domestic violence survivors', 'sexual assault survivors', 'all mental health', 'substance dependency']
column10: ['This program helps people who are 14 to 23 years old.\nThis program serves Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender and Questioning (LGBTQ) youth and young adults, up to the age of 23, and their families/caregivers (biological or by choice)']
column12: The Counseling Department of The Attic Youth Center provides counseling services to LGBTQ youth and young adults and their families/caregivers (biological or by choice). This service uses an LGBTQ affirmative and strength based approach that it is contextual, developmental and culturally sensitive.  This program provides: - Individual therapy- Group therapy- Family and couples therapyThe Attic's clinical team is skilled in addressing a variety of challenges including:- Coming out- Gender questions- Problems at school- Depression and anxiety- Trauma and PTSD- Sexual abuse- Substance abuse- Violence and domestic violence- Anger management- Immigration transitions- Developmental delays- Behavioral and family dynamics as related to the LGBTQ experienceAll Attic counselors and therapists are masters or PhD level and have significant experience working with LGBTQ youth.  To inquire about counseling or to make an appointment, please call The Attic's counseling line and leave a confidential voicemail message with your name and the best way to reach you. A staff member will return your call. You can also reach out by email.All counseling services are currently virtual.

column1: Neighbor to Neighbor Community Development Corporation Inc_Food Cupboard
column10: ['This program serves Delaware County residents.']
column12: Neighbor to Neighbor's Food Cupboard, a food program, for Delaware County residents, delivers urgently needed food to low-income community residents. Each food package provides breakfast, lunch and dinner.This program provides:- Fresh vegetables & fruits- Dairy items- Eggs- Canned goods- Baked goods & pastries- Cereal- Poultry, fish, & meatWhen available, infant foods dietary supplements are distributed.Eligible households receive food packages one Thursday per month. Food packages may also be distributed on an emergency or one-time basis for any community household in need.In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, Neighbor to Neighbor Community Development Corporation, Inc. is no longer permitting non-essential staff inside of our building. When you arrive to utilize the food pantry. Please remain outside and a staff member will come to you.

column1: Jewish Relief Agency_Food Assistance and Relief
column10: ['This program helps people with income at or below 150% of federal poverty guidelines.\nMust live in one of the zip codes we service.']
column12: JRA delivers a 15 lbs. box of food monthly via a no-contact drop-off. This program provides:- A monthly supplemental box of kosher pantry staples and fresh produce (from October to April) delivered directly to your door by one of our friendly volunteers. (Knock, Drop, and Go). - A supplemental bag of kid-friendly food items for families with children ages 18 and under. - Donated household items, toiletries, kids' apparel (through a partnership with Cradles to Crayons) diapers and adult incontinence supplies (through a partnership with The Greater Philadelphia Diaper Bank).Some exceptions may apply. For questions, information, or to request services please contact us at (610) 660-0190 or gethelp@jewishrelief.org.

column1: Jewish Family and Children's Service of Greater Philadelphia_Our Closet in Your Neighborhood
column3: ['emergency food', 'food pantry', 'help find housing', 'housing advice', 'clothing', 'navigating the system']
column10: ['Anyone can access this program.']
column12:
Our Closet In Your Neighborhood (OCIYN) is a free mobile program that provides basic necessities of food and clothing, as well as access to services and benefits, to families and individuals in need. The bus visits host sites in under-resourced neighborhoods and central locations with fresh, healthy produce and pantry staples, a mini pop-up clothing shop, and an onsite social worker. 

This program provides: 

- Food
- Clothing
- Navigation services

Visitors receive fresh, locally-sourced produce and pantry staples and are welcome to shop for 10 free, quality items of clothing, shoes, and accessories per person (with a limit of 25 total per family to allow for all to receive what they need). A JFCS social worker is present at every OCIYN event to connect those in need to additional services and benefits for which they may be eligible.

OCIYN also provides customized packages of emergency clothing delivered straight to those in need, as well as food package delivery to homebound clients. 

To learn more about these services or upcoming pop-up events, contact 267-256-2179 or [email_protected].
column18: This program covers residents of the following cities: Philadelphia, PA.

column1: Fresh Start Foundation_Emergency Housing for Veterans
column10: ['This program serves veterans.']
column12: Emergency Housing for Veterans provides short-term housing and a bridge to inpatient services or more permanent living situations. The goal of this program is to ensure that no veteran ever sleep on the street or in a shelter when identified by a VA social worker or if he should present for emergency services at an area VAMC, CBOC, or Vet Center. This program provides:- Temporary emergency housingThe program serves as an emergency entry point into the VA's homeless care system and offers a seamless continuity of medical and mental healthcare, and case management services for veterans in need of emergency housing.

column1: Covenant House Pennsylvania_Youth Services
column4: ['meals', 'medical care', 'counseling', 'financial education', 'navigating the system', 'case management', 'one-on-one support', 'spiritual support', 'advocacy & legal aid']
column10: ['This program helps people who are younger than 21 years old']
column12: Covenant House Pennsylvania offers shelter and supportive services to young people experiencing homelessness. They aim to help homeless young people become healthy, happy, responsible, productive, and ultimately independent adults.This program provides:- A safe, secure environment- Immediate and transitional housing- Rapid rehousing- Meals and food- Case Management- Spiritual Support- Counseling- Physical health, mental health, and drug and alcohol services- Saving and budgeting- Continuing education- Support for LGBTQ individuals- Job readinessThe Crisis Center is open 24 hours per day, seven days per week. There are no shelter fees; however, those staying at the shelter must deposit 75% of their income during their stay. All money is returned upon leaving the shelter. Covenant House is a drug and weapon-free program.

column1: Church World Service Inc_Border Shelter Network and Call Center
column10: ['This program is available to anyone seeking refuge that was recently released from U.S. custody']
column12: Church World Service Inc offers a network of respite shelters to assist those awaiting a court date with the US government after going through US custody. This program provides:- Short-term shelter- Meals- Clothing- Hygiene products- Access to telephones to call loved ones- Connection to resettlement offices, member congregations, sanctuary churches and other service providers that can assist with housing, legal services, support services and resource sharingCWS has refugee and immigration offices spread across different states. Many of these offices are managed through partnerships with local organizations, while some are directly overseen by CWS and as such set the standard for resettlement in local communities.

column1: Addiction Medicine and Health Advocates Inc_Addiction Medicine And Health Advocates
column3: ['addiction & recovery', 'detox', 'outpatient treatment', 'understand mental health', 'group therapy', 'substance abuse counseling', 'family counseling', 'mental health evaluation', 'drug testing', 'navigating the system', 'support network', 'one-on-one support']
column10: [Follow the Next Steps to find out if this program has eligibility criteria.]
column12: Addiction Medicine and Health Advocates, Inc. (AMHA) provides evidence-based substance abuse treatment, which is continuously responsive to the needs of the patients and their families. AMHA is an outpatient facility consisting of two levels of care: Outpatient and Intensive Outpatient. Methadone Maintenance is provided on both levels of care.Services provided include: Assessment and intake Medication-assisted treatment (methadone maintenance) Individual counseling & psychotherapy Group psychotherapy Psycho education Medical & psychiatric evaluations  Aftercare & follow up services  Referrals (educational, medical, vocational, psychiatric, higher levels of care) Couples & family therapy Drug screening To begin the admissions process, please contact us. You may also come in person between the hours of 9 am and 4 pm, Monday through Friday. You will be asked to complete a short screening interview and if initial eligibility criteria is met, you will be scheduled for an assessment.At the time of your assessment, you will need to bring: Current, state-issued photo ID Insurance cardAMHA is a private not-for-profit organization dependent upon patient fees for its continuance. Most of our patients have some form of insurance or medical assistance that pays for medication-assisted treatment services. Individuals who do not have insurance are responsible for payment or they may be eligible for county funding.
column18: This program covers residents of the following counties: Philadelphia County, PA.
